Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Historical contingency in ecology and restoration: environmental change, year effects, and priority effects in California grasslands
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores how climate variation affects species in California grasslands. It builds on a long-term experiment in which different plants were planted in different plots, then monitored for many years. A four-year drought provided an unexpectedly strong test of how those plants respond to extreme stress. In the winter and spring of 2017, the drought suddenly ended; rainfall returned to normal levels. This dramatic change in conditions is a rare event and will likely have a strong influence on the types of plants that still live in the plots. Funding provided by this award will allow scientists to continue the experiment for at least another year to measure that influence. Understanding how cycles of rainfall influence plants is important for management of grasslands in light of possible long-term shifts in weather.

This is a short-term continuation of a long-term project that, unfortunately, expired just as the drought was ending. The experiment extended by this award tests two opposing models of how natural communities develop after disturbance. One theory predicts that community composition will tend to return to the pre-disturbance state, regardless of the vagaries of early establishment. The other theory predicts that community composition is largely determined priority effects (i.e., the order in which species colonize after disturbance). The study will assess how an unexpectedly large disturbance in water availability affects the outcome of community assembly processes. In addition to providing training for students in research, the investigator will assist in local restoration projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This one-year RAPID grant is effectively an extension of our previous NSF project, “Historical contingency, restoration, and climate change: year effects and priority effects in California grasslands” (DEB 10-50543). One of the goals of the original project was to examine how year-to-year variation affects the outcome of restoration projects (and experiments). However, the grant period largely encompassed the three-year (millennial) drought in California (winters of 2012-2015). The RAPID grant provided short-term support to amend our design to include an additional non-drought year of planting (2015/16), which including a set of 2016/17 plantings (overlaid on the previous year’s plantings).  This all went according to plan. Results from previous years’ experiments demonstrated that although these restored communities changed between the first and second yeas after their (final) plantings, they stabilize after that. Therefore our final surveys of these communities were carried out in May of 2019. These final surveys (in both 2018 and 2019, totaling >2000 plots) are currently being analyzed, but they support and extend the results of our overall project, which has produced eight peer-reviewed publications, with two more in preparation (thus far). Presentations include invited talks at UC Santa Barbara and Harvard, and the 2019 annual meetings of the Natural Areas Association and the Society for Ecological Restoration. This research has practical implications for ecological restoration and vegetation management in general, demonstrating the power of planting order to affect community outcomes, but also the importance of a) year of planting, b) local and often subtle site effects. This RAPID grant provided training opportunities for three doctoral students (all women, one from an underrepresented group). Six undergraduate assistants were also involved.
